posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28313149
Visitation usually depends on the severity of the patient's condition. That determines if they go to a high security wing (no vastation for safety reasons) or a low one (usually normal visiting hours.
Don't sweat her getting messed up more. Psych wards are good spots not like what the media portrays.
I've had family, friends, and co-workers cycle through for various issues and they all say it helps. Apparently, it "let's you take a "step outside life" for a bit and actually focus on mental health as the main event" as my best friend has said. And that goon is a certified frequent flyer.
Just make sure to scope out the facility to make sure it's legit, then ask what she wants. There's probably a fuck ton of shame/embarrassment/resentment/etc for her to process on top of the root cause, and she may want/need some space.
Respect her wishes, communicate you have her back, and engage with her Doc. The rest will buff out naturally.

I’m not sure why, but over the last year or so I’ve been thinking about a LOT of relatively inconsequential shit from my youth and viewing it in a wholly negative way. It isn’t even things that are bad; it’s just things that I’ve decided were cringeworthy and looking back makes me wonder why I was such a retard.

Here’s an example:
>wanted to help a friend with a shitty indie movie he was making when we were in 10th grade
>the role I played featured me as a guy with a ridiculously over-the-top Indian accent
>I’m not Indian; I’m white but look a bit Latin
>eventually grow uncomfortable with my role and tell friend I don’t want to do the accent anymore
>he agrees and comes up with the idea of me coughing a bunch in one scene and then suddenly I don’t have the accent anymore
>never saw the actual movie; hated seeing myself on camera

That’s a pretty pointless memory, but a prime example of the kind of things that have been recently popping up and making me feel legitimately bad about myself. What the fuck is this? I’m 31 now; am I just going insane or what?

posts.sub: Death of a pet and retrospectively wasted time
posts.com:
I've had two ferrets for 7 years now, and needed to get one put down a few days ago. He had untreatable lymphoma (it developed when he was on prednisolone for insulinoma, and prednisolone is a treatment for lymphoma), and was getting anal prolapse and groaning/crying out when he'd poop. After his diagnosis his health deteriorated super rapidly, to where he could hardly move and would outright wail while pooping, so I had to get him put down.
There's a lot of things I'm having trouble with, the big ones being the trauma of seeing, hearing, and feeling him in pain in his final days, and everything about how poorly his euthanasia went, but there's one stupid autistic thing that I'd feel comfortable asking here.

Until about a year ago, I would sometimes put off playing with them for a while in order to study more military history (which frustrated me) and get into stupid arguments about it on 4chan (which also frustrated me). I realized recently how negative the overwhelming majority of military history is, but how do I deal with the fact that I wasted time that could have been spent with my positive, loving boy on negative, hateful accounts of human beings killing each other en masse instead? Is it okay to still study SOME military history that isn't quite so negative when his surviving brother doesn't need me, or should I resent it altogether as the overall subject that I wasted my time on? Like, I feel guilty still studying the few conflicts I find interesting, given how guilty I feel for the time I wasted on conflicts that infuriated me, that could have been spent with my baby instead.

Keep your cool and don't act clingy, but at the same time make sure she knows you actively want to spend time around her.
The perfect balance for men (when it comes to dating), is being stoic when they speak, but showing through their actions that they like the woman. You need to feel how the conversation is going, look for feedback loops.

Say something with a tinge of sexual innuendo.

Don't be afraid from saying provocative things from the get go if you're that type of dude. Make her feel your manliness and way of being from the getgo, so she doesn't perceive you as uninterested or friendzonable.

Unbelievably yes. I'm 30, 5'9 and overweight so the girls I get aren't that hot (but all fuckable), but the fact I'm getting girls with some regularity is amazing. My whole 20s was such a desert of sex, getting laid like once a year even when I was in shape. I've learned my face is actually decent looking, but it never mattered because I was such a shutin and socially stunted (even with a good face I was never Chad tier hot where girls would chat ME up)

The keys have been
>cutting out the copes as much as possible
>study and practice (my biggest problem is going into sympathetic nervous response in lively settings people like to meet, but there are techniques to mitigate that I learned practice regularly)
>focusing on staying out of the house
>being the initiator for all things social. I introduce myself and chat with dudes at the mma gym, I pressure my friends into being less shutin, I think up all the places to go and activities. I'm the nexus of the social group bc everyone else seems fine treading water for the rest of their lives.
>talk to everyone in proximity, guys and girls, even if only for a single sentence about the weather. It helps.
>approach girls you like THEN look for signs, not the other way around
>pleasantly disengage if no signs, don't fight to keep convos going
>girls want FUN more than anything. It's the 21st century, they can take care of themselves (even if barely, in some cases), so being a stable provider isn't good in itself anymore. Social prowess, engaging convo, jokes, laughter, excitement is more important than ever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28309285
>cutting out the copes as much as possible
Copes help subdue negative emotion. Negative emotion is actually your instincts' tool to compel you to action. Our brains are wired to conserve energy, so if it can reduce the negative emotion more efficiently, your prefrontal cortex will rationalize coping. Your instincts can't tell the difference and are sated, and you waste another day, week, month online. You'll face an avalanche of boredom, depression, anxiety. Weather it and find courses of action.
>sympathetic nervous response
Techniques I use in the moment that reduce physical symptoms of anxiety
-diaphragmatic breathing
- soften the gaze
-relax pelvic floor
-relax soft palette
-open up posture
-I just realized this week that chewing gum helps keep my jaw from clenching
At first it's tough going out and using these, because you have to remain conscious of every single breath and it's a bit demoralizing seeing how bad you are. Don't let up, go out frequently for a month practicing and it becomes more natural.
>approach girls you like THEN look for signs, not the other way around
Thought this was intuitive. Most guys stand around waiting for girls to give them signals of interest before they approach. That's a bad strategy because chances are you aren't attractive enough to stand out in a crowd to be noticed. If she's cute, you walk up and chat her up, and THEN see if she gives signs of interest.
>girls want FUN more than anything.
What more needs elaboration? Easiest route possible is to always have party drugs available, flash wealth, or be loud boisterous and cocky. Or get into scraps, if u got the guts (I don't lol but just saiyan)
>what do you find to talk about for conversations
Depends on context. Comment on surroundings, destinations, attire, attitude, and beyond that, FORD.

I'm 26, /fit/, white, have a good 6 figure office job, have my own apartment, have my own car, have male friends from high school and college, have hobbies like skiing and spearfishing, go to concerts, read, etc. I lost my virginity 6 months ago to some random girl on Tinder, that's the only time I've ever had sex in my life. I know I'm not ugly because I've been approached by attractive women before in my life.

I've made out with plenty of girls but it never lead to sex. Through high school and most of college I was afraid to ask girls out. It wasn't even just the idea of rejection, but that I had no idea what to do, how to make a move, what's appropriate to do and not to do, how to go on dates, where to bring them, what to talk about, etc. Every part of it was confusing and foreign and I was afraid of doing it and messing it up or making the girl uncomfortable. My first kiss in high school was with some girl who was into me on NYE. Afterwards I pretended not to be interested in her because I was afraid.

Other than a few times that girls came up to me cold and asked for my number, the only way I've ever gotten dates is through apps. On apps I usually get matches, but I'm a very boring texter and don't know what to talk about so they usually don't respond or ghost within a few messages or agree to a date and ghost the day of. Anytime I actually get a first date, they always ghost me after. The dates are always super boring, I don't know what to talk about or how to "be myself" around them and it feels like an interview or an HR meeting. The few times I've gotten farther than that in my life it has ended in super embarrassing cringey things happening, like I'm in a sitcom.

Now that I'm out of college I don't know any women, don't work with any, don't interact with any. I'm not really afraid of them anymore but I don't know how to meet them or how I'm supposed to act around them if I do by chance get their number/a date.

posts.sub: How to ignore sexual past of my crush?
posts.com:
So I have this big crush on this man. He's very kind and sweet, we've known each others for quite a while, we've hooked up sometimes but it never changed anything about us. Though we are very exclusive, so I wish in the back of my head that I could someday have a serious relationship with him, officially.
The problem is, he has a large sexual past. In itself it's fine, the past is the past but some things, I can help but grind my teeth.

For example, he showed me a photo of himself years younger and I recognized that it was when he lived in Spain with his ex gf. Ok, you know it's fine, maybe you feel a pinch if you're a very jealous person but nothing to get emotionally upset about. But you see on the computer in the photo 4chan open, and you remember that, with that girlfriend, they used to make porn videos together and upload them on /b/...
And then that thought just feels like a cold shower.

How do I get over it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd try to isolate what exactly you feel upset about, because the response will be different. If you don't like the idea of him sharing his body at all in the past, that's a personal problem mostly (unreasonable expectations). If you are worried he's a bit of a perv freak, that's a him problem and might be a legitimate thing to think about the role of sex for your own relationships and what you are and aren't comfortable with.

If it's an emotional attachment/jealousy kind of thing, that's yet another side to it that you might need to think deeper about what exact part of it bothers what exact beliefs or insecurities of yours.

And then completely separately, is if he doesn't even consider a long term serious relationship with you like you do, it's not worth the effort and heartbreak and I'd try to ease off.

That being said, it is still dog shit pay and if you're looking to teach abroad, don't do it as a life long career. Anyway, my recommendation would be to literally just google 'English teaching jobs, south korea (or hong kong) and scroll through. Fair warning, South Korea will not hire you if you don't have a college degree. They don't really care what degree you have surprisingly, they just care that you have one. on top of a degree, it is a good idea (although not necessarily required) to get a TEFL certificate. Don't work through TEFL, just get their certificate. It looks good on resumes and shows you at least learned how to teach a bit. the fact that you have some teaching experience will put you ahead of all the newly college graduated people with no experience so make sure to highlight that. >Women of /adv/, why did you choose your boyfriend?
We met on the internet back in 2017. We were immediately drawn to each other from the first time we talked. We had natural chemistry and loved talking to one another. We're both very reserved people and yet it felt so natural to open up to each other. I wasn't doing very well and neither was him, and neither of us is the kind of person to open up with a stranger, but I felt safe with him, and him with me.
I knew we had something special.

From the first time we spent time together in person I knew I was going to marry him. Told my parents about it after one date. My stomach hurt from laughing, I felt completely at ease with him, conversation felt so effortless. I talked to him about things that I struggled to open up about with my lifelong friends.
Our relationship felt like a romance movie. I never felt so intensely about a man, I never felt so clearly loved and wanted. We never wanted to be apart from each other, every minute we spent together was filled with love and desire. I immediately felt like I found my person and I have never felt alone since.
Whether we are reading books to each other until we fall asleep, dancing in the kitchen, making love until we are too sore to get out of bed, staying up all night talking and laughing, hopping in the car because he woke up wanting to go see some cool place with me, or going to the bowling alley at the end of the street on a monday morning, I've felt incredibly blessed every single day of our relationship.

He's very kind, and really just has a child like purity to him - he's empathetic, genuine, loving. He wears his heart on his sleeve. He's always himself and isn't afraid to stand up for the things he believes in, but he's never a dick about it. There was never one time I thought he crossed the line or he acted poorly towards someone. He never raised his voice with me in 5 years we've been together, said anything mean to me during a disagreement.

He loves loving me. He is romantic, always tender and thoughtful, affectionate to the point our friends and families mock us over it. He's brave and willing to take risks, while I'm extremely risk adverse. He encourages me to be a better person and take my chances, and I'm incredibly grateful I have him to cheer me.
He's also just really goofy and dorky. It's a side of him he showed more and more over time, but there's such an adorable silliness about him that I can't get over.
He loves his family so much and it fills my heart with joy. He immediately told me he wanted us to get married and have babies, he never played any games with me and was always straight forward about me and us. He introduced me to his family and friends with pride, put a ring on my finger, bought us a house to raise a family in.
We share a lot of interests, but we're different enough that it's always fun to be with each other. I learnt so much from him, and I love that I got the chance to teach him.
He's pretty introverted, and so am I. I really appreciate that we're each other's world.

On top of all that, he is the most handsome man I've met IRL. I was legitimately shocked the first time I saw him. He has beautiful dark hair and very pale skin. His eyes are kind and look like amber. He has a warm, loving smile that could light up a room. He's tall, strong, lean.
Every person who met him told me he was so handsome and out of my league, and I agree.

I honestly don't know what I've done to deserve a love like our from a man like him, but I'm grateful for it forever. I can't wait for the rest of our life.

I studied philosophy basically before I studied anything else, I was really young, and one of the skin deep truths you understand early in your studies is that meaning can't be found objectively, but as a human you damn well better find it anyway. This is something that goes from Plato to Viktor Frankl, Plato thought an objective meaning to life was self-evident, but by the time we get to Frankl it's more like: "it's not about whether it actually exists or not, but you'll do better if you can live meaningfully"

If you're not sure how to live meaningfully then maybe become a nurse or paramedic. Something where other people will make it feel meaningful.

I have other women friends who are married or dating, but I would never drive eight hours each way and spend the night out of state to hang out with them and their family. I told my ex this last weekend and that I would see her when I was in town next, I just felt strange making a trip to see her and her mom specifically. She got upset and told me I was being unfair and that I was insane to think there would be a problem with us hanging out, and that her boyfriend can’t tell her what to do. I stuck to my guns. posts.com:
My life is insane. I try to tell people about my life and nobody gets it. I just want someone to say either "yah that's pretty much my life, just how it is" or "you should change x, y, and z and your life will be perfect."

On paper I've made it. I married my high school sweetheart (who now has chronic health issues and is hard to take care of), we have 4 kids, and I have a successful career (senior engineer at a large tech company, my w-2 has a quarter mil on it this year). I workout daily and am in the best shape of my life even though I'm mid 30s.

But, I have no free time. I have no friends. I abuse stimulants and only sleep a few hours a day. I don't even remember the last time I slept in a bed. I usually just fall asleep wherever I'm doing stuff. Every second of my day is optimized for productivity. I'm either working (in some capacity), cleaning, or cooking. Even now I'm writing this post on an exercise bike because that's the only time I use social media (I leave my phone in my car until now so I don't get distracted, and I have blocks on all social media on my work computer). My day looks like this:

7am kids wake me up, get them breakfast/dressed, answer emails
9am go to work (30min commute)
4pm come home, do garage chores (open packages, do garbage, etc) hug my kids, talk about the day
6pm do dishes from the day, make dinner
830pm give everyone a bath, read a book, get them in bed
11pm the last kid falls asleep, do HIIT cardio to spike cortisol so I don't fall asleep
12pm do more dishes, clean kitchen, laundry, misc chores like cleaning bathrooms, vacuum, mop, whatever
2am take a shower, then work more until I fall asleep around 4am

1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used to love playing video games, socializing, or just watching TV with my wife, but there's no time for any of that. I do listen to books and podcasts while I do chores at least. If anything goes even a bit wrong (eg someone gets sick, an appliance breaks, flat tire, anything) it completely fucks up my life because now it turns into a game of pick what doesn't get done. Maybe we skip dinner. Maybe we live with mold in the shower this week. The idea of getting a hobby or joining a men's group sounds actually impossible.

Then there's money. I live paycheck to paycheck and everyone acts like this is crazy and impossible because I have a high income. Yeah I have 401k savings and 529 accounts, but my takehome pay is just over $9k. That sounds like a lot, but take your current living expenses and multiply them by 6 and it should make sense. $3k mortgage, $1.2k for two modest cars+fuel+ins, $1k for utilities, $3.5k for groceries (food+diapers+soap, etc) and a bit over $1k to clothe everyone and pay for any kind of incidental, which are unending when you have 4 kids. We got our winter clothes at Goodwill for christsake, and my total comp was over $300k this year. I'm doing good, don't get me wrong but I've had the same shoes for 3 years, the same mid tier laptop for 5 years, 10+ year old furniture, etc. I'm not living in a mansion with everything I want like people imagine. I had more disposable income as a college student. I'm getting by with whatever is cheapest and telling my kids they can only pick one sport because we can't afford two.

Nobody I know has children. Nobody in my family. None of my coworkers. So whenever I describe my life, they act like I'm insane. I have zero support system on top of this. No close family, no sitters, no friends. I try to talk to other parents at places but they're some of the my most antisocial people I've ever met. They drop their kids off at wherever then fuck off. I don't get it.

2/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had a church group before kids but none of them had kids, or planned to have kids, and they more or less kicked my wife and I out when we had our first. I joined a men's group at a different church a few years ago but none of them had kids/half were retired so hard to commiserate. I don't even go to church anymore because I use that time to go grocery shopping and do chores.

The scale of childlessness among what should be my peers is astonishing. If you want a world that's better in the future than the one we have today, you have to actually have kids for there to be a future, and then do moral productive work to make the world better. The fact that people are increasingly childless, and we're constantly burdening young people with more work and less pay during their short fertile years, with political and social pressure to not have kids for a myriad of reasons... Idk, it feels like a giant social contract has been broken. Like the world views my success as their failure, and they should make the lives of working parents like me as difficult as possible.

I've made it. I have more than I ever dreamed I could have. My life in incredibly fulfilling and I'm proud of the life and family I've built. I just don't think it's supposed to be this hard.

Inb4
>Six figures is a lot of money you just have a spending problem, never complain again
>Your fault for having kids, never complain again
>Some people/I have it worse, never complain again
>At least you have X, never complain again
>Why are you trying so hard? You shouldn't even try

3/3

tl:dr You had 4 kids and your wife doesn't seem like she is doing anything, so either make her do more stuff or cut some expenses that maybe your peers can afford but not you.

6 hours in office, but maybe 9 hours total per day

The kids with the sleep, my pediatrician balks at this but I don't know what's normal because I don't talk to other parents. My oldest never slept for shit. She goes to bed late and wakes up early and stopped taking naps when she was 2. She's ADHD and I genuinely wonder if she has some kind of genetic, cognitive whatever that just makes her need less sleep. Her and the youngest are always up past 11 (baby boy gets to sleep in tho). The other two crash by 10 and it's an act of Congress to wake them up in the morning.

The cleaning is minimal and half assed. 2 hours to clean a kitchen (clear and wipe a table with food all over everything, unload/reload dishwasher, wipe down surfaces), do 1-2 loads of laundry, and one add on weekly task (bleach a bathroom, mop hard floor, whatever) seems reasonable. My rough estimates are 15 minutes to wipe table/floor, 5 minutes unload, 15-25 minutes to load (depends on how caked on food is), 5 minutes wipe down/misc cleanup, then laundry takes maybe 5 minutes to turn over but 15 or so to fold, master bath is a 40 minute clean, others are 25ish, mopping takes 30+ usually, idk how. I had this all in a spreadsheet when I was trying to fix my life. If not cleaning there's usually some other bullshit, like I'm trying to glue a dollhouse fencepost back together tonight, and reorganizing the bullshit plate cabinet because my wife wants me to replace the Christmas bowl centerpiece with the valentine's day one and I have to go figure it where it is. There's type 1 fun, where you enjoy it while you're doing it (eg video games)
There's type 2 fun, where you enjoy it after you did it (eg workout, cleaning house)
Then there's type 3 fun where you hated doing it, you hate it after it's over, and it's years until you look back on it with any sort of fondness (raising kids, military service, taking care of your dying spouse)

My life is very fulfilling (type 2/3 fun) but I'm not happy (in a type 1 fun way). Which is fine, I'm not upset about that. You look at any hero story, real or fictional, and their life fucking sucks until they fight and win. Luke Skywalker, Harry Potter, George Washington, whoever, has zero type 1 fun. I am a fool who doesn't know what they want, and over a series of three months, prompted by the death of a very close loved one and of my old childhood dog a month later, I have made a number of foolish choices. I've diy'd tranny drugs by ordering injection vials online for two months and am almost certainly sterile now. I've been spending my savings on long drives and paying people to get me drinks from the liquor store, and I've been drinking pretty often lately even though I know my family's predisposition to alcoholism is very strong. I've lost 30 pounds. I've shut myself off from anyone vaguely resembling a friend and only now speak the normal smalltalk with my classmates at the college. In spite of my drinking I'm doing better than ever in my classes and am rolling in the 100s on tests, but I'm sure that winning streak will expire. I wasn't even fine before this since I was a terribly socially anxious piece of shit for most of my life, so even though I can make smalltalk now, it's still all quick heartbeats and second thoughts. And frankly, I'm in a degree that is essentially one I chose because I was afraid I couldn't make it in the one I wanted.

So it's pretty much over, right? I can't even have children now, but I probably was never going to anyways since I was already a fag. I feel like I'm not even living in the right world anymore, like so much was taken away from me so quickly and now I'm just waiting for a chance to go home to normal, even though things will never be normal again. Unironically would I just be better off anhero'ing? I have a shotty, so I wouldn't have to bother with bullshit that might not work. I've been thinking that I could just get it, drive deep into a nature reserve, and remove myself. Then nobody would know, nobody would have to clean me up, nobody would be traumatized. At worst they'd just miss me and be troubled by why I disappeared one day. I just don't know. This sucks anons. I just want things to go back to normal again.

it’s only over when you say it’s over. or i guess if you get struck by lightning LOL. no but listen anon, if you’re thinking about killing yourself i’d suggest you first sell all of your belongings and do something like hiking the appalachian trail or backpacking across europe as cliche as those are.

just like buying a car, you need to do your research on what’s out there. if you think you want to cash out early, it’s final so you might as well double check to make sure you’re not missing anything. like that point in a lot of open world rpgs where they warn you that you’re about to enter the endgame, so you’ll want to wrap up any sidequests you might have missed or forgotten about.

while you’re out there it might get dangerous and you could get robbed or killed or whatever, but the bright side is that you’re already planning on killings yourself, so you won’t really have need of your belongings or life for too long anyway. it’s kind of like if somebody broke into your home and stole that ugly lamp you were about to throw out anyway. in the face of pulling the plug on everything, all those dangers should seem silly.

if you still want to kill yourself after that, can’t say i agree with the decision but you’ve at least done your research and that’s more than most. ultimately the choice is yours, as it is with everybody, and i guess that’s both a freedom and a responsibility. for what it’s worth, i hope you get your head on straight at some point within the next five or so years.

Despite this, it only has to happen once to send your marriage into a tailspin of suspicion and distrust. Going down this path, you can't put toothpaste back in the tube.

>no fapping

>no 4chan
Let me say that again
>NO 4CHAN
>No vidya
>no music
>no porn
>no social media
>No YouTube
>no algorithm searching ANYTHING

There's a lot of science to unwrap with the risk reward pathway, and ADHD is particularly even more complex because it involves many circuits, but this doc gives a thorough explanation of what a real dopamine detox would entail
>https://youtu.be/wK-s2qBU40A

Basically, a normal coomer/gamer has fried his dopamine receptors from years of abuse and reward seeking behaviors. We call this effect on the brain dopamine downregulation. ADHD is this same effect, but essentially on 20x steroid levels. You need a solid ~2 weeks of strict fasting to even begin the process of healing, and closer to 2 months of living like a monk to really get full blown upregulation to the levels you had before you began cooming and shitposting.

>>28314188
There's a difference between "making mistakes" deliberately choosing to do wrong. A mistake would be, say, a woman marrying a guy who put on a charming front and only turned into a psychopath after the wedding. Or calling off a marriage because she had very strong but circumstantial evidence that her fiance cheated, even though it was all a misunderstanding and he was loyal. These are understandable actions that led to bad outcomes because of imperfect information. Not deliberate and intrinsic wrongs.

If you don't care about waiting until marriage, then sure, it doesn't make sense to get upset that women didn't wait, but any moral standard that you do have--like about infidelity--is absolutely a relevant concern to have in a partner's past. It shows what that person is capable of, and what they truly value. And having wider social consequences for doing wrong is an important part of discouraging people from making "mistakes" in the first place.
It isn't a noble position to say you wouldn't care about what your partner did in the past. It's a very selfish one, since you are willing to send a message that doing wrong has few consequences in exchange for the mere *belief* that you get a pleasant relationship in the present. You don't need to, and shouldn't, attack someone for a past they regret and can't change. But neither are you obligated to ignore it, and if they genuinely regret it, they themselves should accept that.

>> because we exported all our jobs and imported a whole ton of immigrants that finding a job around here is almost impossible.

This is entirely and completely false. Every western country in the OECD has done the same thing. There are mountains of opportunities, you just have to be bothered to get off your ass and find them.

Immigration is high because birth rates are not, and there are major skills shortages.

https://nwivisas.com/nwi-blog/canada/canadas-skilled-occupation-list-noc-skills-shortage-list-2022-2023/

Every role on this list has people in short supply. They're actively seeking to upskill people into these roles.

What happened was millennials and zoomers thought they had to go to university to get somewhere, which left an entire 1/3 of the market open without any new skilled labour and a massive oversupply in the rest of the market.

If locals won't do the jobs, the government has no choice but to import people to do those jobs. Every high school graduate should be looking at that list before they decide what they want to do.

Many of these skills are learned on the job through traineeships, internships and apprenticeships. Because there's a shortage many of these roles are also paying very well.
